Arithmetic Progression

  • \(\mathbf{Sequence}\):Arrangement of numbers in a definite order according to some rule. We can also define sequence as a function whose domain is the set of natural numbers or some subset of the type \([1,2,3,\ldots ,k]\).
    • \(\mathbf{Terms}\):Each of the numbers in the sequence is known as terms.A sequence with finite number of terms is called a finite sequence.A sequence is called a infinite sequence if it is not a finite sequence.
  • \(\mathbf{Series}\): let \(a_1,a_2,a_3, \ldots \) be a sequence, then the sum expressed as \(a_1+a_2+a_3+\cdots \) is called a series. A series is called finite series if it has got finite number of terms
  • \(\mathbf{Arithmetic}\) \(\mathbf{Progression (A.P)}\):Any sequence be an arithmetic progression if and only if it has a constant difference between every two consecutive terms.
    • \(\mathbf{Common}\) \(\mathbf{Difference}\): The constant difference between two consecutive terms is know as common difference. The common difference may be positive,negative or zero
    • \(\mathbf{Genaral}\) \(\mathbf{Form}\): General form of an A.P. is $$a,(a+d),(a+2d), \ldots $$ Where, \(a\) is the first term of the A.P. and \(d\) is the common difference.
    • Minimum informations required to form an A.P. are it's first term and common difference.
    • \(\mathbf{n^{th}} \)\(\mathbf{Term}\) or \(\mathbf{General}\) \(\mathbf{Term}\): \(n^{th}\) term \ General term of an A.P. is given by $$a_n=a+(n-1)d$$
    • \(\mathbf{Sum}\) \(\mathbf{of}\) \(\mathbf{n}\) \(\mathbf{terms}\): Sum of first n terms of an A.P. is given by $$S_n=\frac n2 \left[2a+(n-1)d\right]$$
    • \(\mathbf{Arithmetic}\) \(\mathbf{Mean(A.M.)}\): Arithmetic mean of any two numbers a and b is given by $$A.M.=\frac{a+b}{2}$$
  • To form an A.P. by inserting \(m\) numbers between a and b, the common difference should be $$d=\frac {b-a}{m+1}$$
